fields.name: Size your water heater
fields.content: You'll need to know how many gallons your water heater holds. Your manual will provide this information, but most homes use hot water heaters that hold 30-50 gallons.Nunan, Jon. "Hot Water Needs" Service Magic. n.d. 20 Jan. 2010

fields.name: Buy an insulation kit
fields.content: Most hot water insulating kits are fairly inexpensive ? usually under $20. Look for one that has an R-value of 8 or more, like the Frost King model. Adding insulation will save you 4-9% in water heating costs."Insulate Your Water Heater Tank for Energy Savings" Energy Savers. U.S. Department of Energy. 24 March 2009. 19 Jan 2010

fields.name: Install the insulation
fields.content: You can easily install it yourself with some scissors and tape. Your kit may come with its own instructions, but here is a set of general step-by-step instructions. If you have a gas-powered water heater, make sure to keep the insulation away from the flue.

fields.name: Buy an Energy Star-rated refrigerator
fields.content: Look for the blue Energy Star label when selecting your appliance. Energy Star refrigerators use 20% less energy than similar, non-certified models." This calculator will tell you how much more energy you current fridge is wasting when compared to a new model. You can find an Energy Star model for almost any type of refrigerator, giving you access to all the latest features.

fields.name: Set your water heater to 120°F
fields.content: Your owner?s manual will include instructions about how to adjust the temperature setting. If you can't find your manual, it's usually fairly easy to find your heater's thermostat. This article from Popular Mechanics gives a good description of how to set the temperature for electric, gas, and oil powered water heaters.

fields.name: Identify an auditor
fields.content: The Repower@Home database will connect you with a qualified auditor in your neighborhood. Repower@Home only lists inspectors who are certified by Energy Star, so you know you'll be receiving high-quality work.

fields.name: Schedule an appointment
fields.content: Pick a time when you'll be able to devote a few hours to walking through your home with the auditors.

fields.name: Organize your documents
fields.content: Think of any concerns you may already have and collect your recent utility bills.

fields.name: Meet the auditor and begin improving your home
Buy insulation
fields.content: Insulation is very inexpensive and commonly available. The diameter of your pipe should match the diameter of the sleeve for a snug fit.

fields.name: Install the insulation
fields.content: This is a very similar project to insulating your hot water heater: cut, wrap, and tape. The most important pipes are the ones that are three feet or closer to your hot water heater.California Energy Commission, Increasing Your Water Heater's Efficiency

fields.name: Size your fireplace
fields.content: It's important that the chimney draft guard fits snugly.

fields.name: Switch your wash cycle
fields.content: If you wash 80% of your loads in cold water for a year, you'll save more than $60 in energy costs.Planet Green, Beat the Heat, Wash in Cold There are many laundry detergents available that are specifically formulated to work with cold water, including Tide Coldwash and Woolite Liquid Cold Water Wash. As an added benefit of switching cycles, your clothes will last longer if they're washed in cold water.

fields.name: Buy a power strip
fields.content: You can eliminate vampire power by connecting all your electronics to power strips, and switching off the power strip after you're done using your devices. It's easy to forget to switch off your power strip every time, so "smart" power strips are here to make destroying vampire power even easier. They cut power to your electronics, either by linking all devices on the strip to a single control or by automatically switching everything off when one device, like the television, is powered down. They're perfect for the home entertainment or office areas.

fields.name: Use the power strip
fields.content: Plug in your devices and start saving! Make sure you remember to switch your power strip off, or you won't actually see any savings.

fields.name: Identify the correct model for your home
fields.content: There are a wide range of thermostats for many different types of heating systems, budgets, and habits.  Some thermostats give you the ability to program several different settings for each day of the week.

fields.name: Purchase the thermostat
fields.content: Buy the right thermostat for your system. If your home has electric heat, make sure to select one specifically for that system. Programmable thermostats are generally not compatible with heat pumps.

fields.name: Install the thermostat
fields.content: If you already have a manual thermostat, you can probably install a programmable one yourself.

fields.name: Program the thermostat
fields.content: Think about when you typically go to bed, leave in the morning, and come home at night. Set your thermostat to lower your heat or air-conditioning while you're asleep or at work, and turn the heat back up by the time you wake up or get home. During the winter, rolling back your thermostat from 72° to 65° for eight hours a day will save you 7% on your heating bill.Department of Energy, Energy Savers,

fields.name: Experiment to find a comfortable temperature
fields.content: The difference between 78° and 74° may not feel like much, but it has a big impact on your energy use. By permanently setting your thermostat to 78° instead of 74° during the summer, you'll save around 12% on your cooling bill.Christopher Solomon, MSN Real Estate 14 ways to lower your heating bill The same is true in the winter; try setting your thermostat to 70° or 68° instead of 72°.

fields.name: Measure which vents you want to seal
fields.content: If your vents can easily be closed, you may not even need a vent cover.

fields.name: Buy the vent cover
fields.content: Magnetic vent covers stay in place, but are also easy to remove

fields.name: Change your filters every three months
fields.content: Don't underestimate the benefits of new filters. Clean filters help your system run efficiently, last longer, and create better indoor air quality.

fields.name: Raise your thermostat
fields.content: If you have a fan installed properly, you can raise your thermostat by four degrees and not feel any hotter.Novak, Sara. "Use Fans, Turn the Thermostat Up 4 Degrees." Planet Green. 2 Aug 2009. 25 Jan 2010. Consistently keeping your thermostat four degrees higher in the summer will save you around 12% on your summer cooling bill."3 percent to 5 percent more energy is used for each degree the furnace is set above 68 degrees and for each degree the air conditioner is set below 78 degrees," "Energy Saving Tips. PG&E. n.d. 25 Jan 2010.

fields.name: Identify lights that are often left on
fields.content: Common culprits can be found in hallways, bathrooms, and porches.

fields.name: Decide between a motion sensor or a timer
fields.content: Motion sensors are a good choice for hallways and bathrooms. A timer can help you set your porch lights to go off at sunrise or turn off  lights by windows after a certain amount of time.

fields.name: Install
fields.content: Sensors and motion detectors are easy to install and operate. Once you set it up, plug it in and start enjoying automatic savings.

fields.name: Close the damper
fields.content: Check to make sure your damper is closed when you're not using your fireplace. Open dampers are like open windows in the middle of winter!

fields.name: Buy a low-flow shower head
fields.content: You can find them at any local home improvement store. Starting in 2010, these high efficiency shower heads will carry the EPA WaterSense logo, making them easy to identify. Low-flow shower heads have a flow rate of less than 2.0 gpm, but most homes only need a 1.5 gpm shower head. The flow rate should be listed on the box. Every shower you take will use 25% less water and energy if you opt for a 1.5gpm shower head over a 2.0 gpm model.

fields.name: Install the shower head
fields.content: You can easily do the installation yourself. For step-by-step instructions, refer to this article.

fields.name: Reverse the direction of your fan
fields.content: Warm air rises and sits near the ceiling, while it feels much colder on the floor. During the winter, reverse the direction of your ceiling fan. Warm air will now be pushed down, making the room feel warmer. This is particularly useful for homes with ceilings above 8 feet tall.

fields.name: Lower your thermostat
fields.content: Turning the fan on only saves energy if you also lower your heat. Experiment to find a comfortable setting. You should be able lower your thermostat enough to still feel comfortable and save around 10% on your heating bills.Kristin Underwood, Treehugger.com Turn Back Your Clock and Fan This Halloween for Better Energy Savings

fields.name: Buy a sink aerator
fields.content: Sink aerators - small pieces that attach to your sinks - are widely available and very inexpensive: from about 50 cents to $3.00. For the bathroom, look for an aerator with a flow rate of between 0.5 to 1 gallon per minute. You can also install aerators in your kitchen, but kitchen sinks need a higher flow rate. Low-flow bathroom faucets can reduce a sink's water flow by 30 percent or more without sacrificing performance.EPA, WaterSense, Bathroom Sink Faucets & Accessories Look for the EPA WaterSense logo on aerators to ensure you're purchasing a low-flow version. The website MetaEfficient has reviews and purchasing information for some of the most popular sink aerators.

fields.name: Install the aerator
fields.content: It will screw right on to the bottom of most faucets.

fields.name: Assess your needs
fields.content: CFLs can be used virtually everywhere. Certain CFLs can even be used with dimmers and other specialty lights. To find the right CFL for you, consult the Energy Star Buyer's Guide.

fields.name: Buy the light bulbs
fields.content: CFLs are widely available. CFLs are a bit more expensive, but you'll easily recoup your investment in energy savings. One CFL will save you $30 over the bulb's lifetime, paying for itself in around six months.ENERGY STAR, "Green" Light Bulb Buying Guide CFLs also last up to ten times longer, meaning fewer trips to the hardware store.

fields.name: Select your caulk
fields.content: You can buy caulk at virtually any hardware store. There are many different types of caulk available, but make sure you select a caulk designed to seal dissimilar materials. Butyl rubber caulk is one good choice.

fields.name: Clean the surface
fields.content: Wipe down the surface and scrape away any old caulk with a putty knife or screw driver. Make sure the surface is completely dry before you start.

fields.name: Caulk
fields.content:
Make sure to put caulk where the glass meets the frame and in the frame's joints. Caulking is an improvement you can easily do yourself, but it can take some practice to get it perfect. To perfect your form, try:
  • Holding the gun at a 45º angle, so the caulk is forced into cracks as it comes out.
  • Caulking continually, without multiple stops and starts.
  • Having the caulk stick to both sides of a gap.

fields.name: Buy a window insulation kit
fields.content: Window insulation kits contain a special plastic sheet and double-sided tape. The sheet traps air between the sheet and glass, creating an insulating barrier. Kits - like those from 3M and Ace - are easy to install and generally cost less than $4 per window.

fields.name: Install the kit
fields.content: With just some scissors and a few minutes, you can stop uncomfortable drafts.

fields.name: Select high-performance windows
fields.content:
The most energy efficient windows are double-paned and constructed with high-performance glass. "High- performance" means the glass is able to absorb or reflect light better than conventional glass. In cold areas, for example, "low-e" windows are a good choice. They readily absorb heat and reflect it back into the room. In warm areas, "spectrally selective" glass reduces heat gain while allowing light to pass through. 

Choosing the right window will make a big difference in your energy bills. A contractor will be able to tailor recommendations to your home's needs.

fields.name: Activate energy-saving settings
fields.content:
It's easy to customize your power management preferences. Set your computer to enter standby or hibernate mode after 30 to 60 minutes of inactivity. Have the monitor turn off after 20 minutes of inactivity.
  • For Windows Users: Start -> Control Panel -> Performance and Maintenance -> Power Options
  • For Mac Users: Applications -> System Preferences -> Energy Saver
